title: Past: Historical Ecosystems
text:
BpS models represent the vegetation system that may have been dominant on the landscape prior to Euro-American settlement. These models are based on a combination of the current environment and an approximation of the historical disturbance regime. Read more.

Check out this 3-minute tutorial for a quick refresher on the basics of Biophysical Settings Models.
Use this page as a starting point to explore the most prevalent BpSs on the Midewin Natioanal Tallgrass Prairie. In addition to the charts and maps, the historical disturbance data can be directly accessed using this site.

title: Past: Historical Ecosystems
text:
Summary

As expected, most of the area was mapped as being dominated by very fire-adapted ecosystems prior to European Colonization, the Central Tallgrass Prairie and the Dry-Mesic Oak Forest and Woodland.
Almost the entire national grassland had a fire return interval of < 13 years.
There were a total of 7 Biophysical Settings mapped, with the aforementioned 2 covering all but ~500 acres total.

title: Comparisons
text:
Using LANDFIRE’s BpS products, we explore two different ways to visualize past vs. current vegetation patterns.

First we present changes in broad ecosystem types using an interactive comparison diagram. To present these broad ecosystem trends more effectively, we combined classifications of Existing Vegetation Types (EVT) into broader categories.Developed EVTs of high, medium, and low intensity, and Quarries-Strip Mines-Gravel Pits EVTs were combined into one “Developed” EVT. Exotic Herbaceous and Exotic Tree-shrub EVTs were combined into one “Exotics” EVT.
Second we compare amounts of succession classes (past and present) for the most prevalent ecosystems.

title: Comparisons
text:
Using LANDFIRE’s BpS products, we explore two different ways to visualize past vs. current vegetation patterns.

First we present changes in broad ecosystem types using an interactive comparison diagram. To present these broad ecosystem trends more effectively, we combined classifications of Existing Vegetation Types (EVT) into broader categories.Developed EVTs of high, medium, and low intensity, and Quarries-Strip Mines-Gravel Pits EVTs were combined into one “Developed” EVT. Exotic Herbaceous and Exotic Tree-shrub EVTs were combined into one “Exotics” EVT.
Second we compare amounts of succession classes (past and present) for the most prevalent ecosystems.

title: Comparisons
text:
Comparing Broad Vegetation Trends

Summary
There has not been broad conversion of ecosystems from one type to another (see circular chord diagram below). However, some patterns are worth noting:

Interestingly, there has been a broad-scale change from ‘hardwood’ type to more ‘conifer’ types. Likely due primarily to conversion of hardwood to pine for timber production.
There has been some conversion from past conifer, past hardwood, past hardwood-conifer, and past grassland to developed and agricultural types, though overall, the forest remains heavily forested.
Acres of grassland have been dramatically reduced. Almost all of the past 30,000 acres of grassland have been converted to agriculture, exotic, and forested types.
Exotic types now represent roughly 55,000 acres of the forest.

Note: number presented when hovering equals acres.

title: Comparisons
section: Succession classes for three most dominant BpSs
text:
Succession classes for three most dominant BpSs
Some shifts in succession classes were quite interesting in these three communities.

There was a increase in succession class E, in all three ecosystems. Succession class E is characterized as closed canopy (>71% canopy cover) wiht a sparse herbaceous understory. As fire has been identified as the most prevalent disturbance on this landscape, this shift is presumably due to lack of fire on the landscape.
The ‘Ozark-Ouachita Shortleaf Pine-Bluestem Woodland’ community has the most dramatic shift in succession class, with much of the past Succession Class D and C, described as mid to late-seral woodland savannah with pine oak overstory and bluestem grass understory representative of this community, shifting to closed canopy (Succession Class E).
All three ecosystems had dramatic reductions in Succession Classes A, B, and C. These succession classes are early and mid development classes, with seedling and sapling trees (Class A) to midstory trees (< 10m tree height) (Class B and C). Overall, this trend suggests that in the past, higher intensity or frequency of disturbance (primarily fire) shifted ecosystems into, and maintained, these earlier development succession classes.

title: About this Project
text: This project is the result of a meaningful collaboration across The Nature Conservancy, and serves as an demonstration of data products that may be created using LANDFIRE data. These charts, maps, and graphs are based on current LANDFIRE products, and provide a starting point for further analysis. All maps, input datasets and further assistance can be obtained by contacting the author, Randy Swaty and Melanie Rudolf, Nature Conservancy Ecologists.

title: About this Project
text:
The Nature Conservancy & LANDFIRE
LANDFIRE, Landscape Fire and Resource Management Planning Tools, is a shared program between the wildland fire management programs of the U.S. Department of Agriculture Forest Service, the U.S. Department of the Interior, and The Nature Conservancy, that provides landscape-scale geo-spatial products, vegetation models and tools to support cross-boundary planning, management, and operations.
The Nature Conservancy supports LANDFIRE through

“Advancing conservation outcomes through collaborative ecosystem science.”
— Visit the LANDFIRE website

LANDFIRE provides 25+ national geo-spatial layers (e.g. vegetation, fuel, disturbance, etc.), databases, and ecological models that are available to the public for the U.S. and insular areas. These nationwide geospatial data products reflect current and historic conditions and include ecosystem dynamic models that can be used for conservation, fire planning, and land management decisions.

title: About this Project
text:
Biophysical Settings Products

Quick intro
A Biophysical Setting (BpS) is a concept that represents the vegetation that may have been dominant on the landscape prior to European colonization of North America and is based on both the current biophysical environment and an approximation of the historical disturbance regime.
LANDFIRE collaborated with experts around the country to create a description and model for every BpS it mapped across the US.
Check out the vegetation modeling website to learn how to integrate BpS into your work.


Resources

Vegetation dynamics models: a comprehensive set for natural resource assessment and planning in the United States. Kori Blankenship, Randy Swaty, Kimberly R. Hall, Sarah Hagen, Kelly Pohl, Ayn Shlisky Hunt, Jeannie Patton, Leonardo Frid, Jim Smith
BpS Descriptions and Models information
Information about the BpS Spatial Data

title: About this Project
text:
Vegetation Products

Quick Intro
LANDFIRE (LF) existing vegetation layers describe the following elements: Existing Vegetation Type (EVT), Existing Vegetation Canopy Cover (EVC), and Existing Vegetation Height (EVH). These layers are created using predictive landscape models based on extensive field-referenced data, satellite imagery and biophysical gradient layers using classification and regression trees.’ (from https://landfire.gov/vegetation.php)


Resources

Existing Vegetation Cover
Existing Vegetation Height
Existing Vegetation Type

title: Midewin Natioanal Tallgrass Prairie Landscape Assessment
text:
We will use LANDFIRE products to:

Characterize and map past and present ecosystem conditions.
Explore historical disturbance patterns.
Summarize patterns of change and management opportunities.

The following charts, maps, and graphs are based on current LANDFIRE products, and provide a starting point for further analysis.
This demonstration will:

Provide context for the past and present ecosystem conditions the Midewin Natioanal Tallgrass Prairie.
Demonstrate the power of data visualization to explore ecological patterns and functions using LANDFIRE products.
Facilitate an understanding of historical and current conditions on a regional scale.

title: Present: Current Ecosystem Conditions
text:
LANDFIRE’s Existing Vegetation Type, Cover and Height datasets describe vegetation conditions.
Read more about LANDFIRE Vegetation Products

title: Present: Current Ecosystem Conditions
text:
Summary
In general the Ouachita National Forest, as of 2022, has experienced some interesting changes in natural ecosystems. However, care should be taken when directly comparing past and present maps, as classification systems for present Biophysical Settings have been updated to align with the most current NatureServe (2016) ecosystem descriptions. With this caveat in mind, some patterns are worth noting:

Shortleaf pine and oak dominated systems are still the most prevalent vegetation types on the forest, though much of the vegetation types have shifted from “woodland” descriptions to more “forest” descriptions, indicating an increase in canopy cover.
The most prevalent past Biophysical Setting, ‘Ozark-Ouachita Shortleaf-Pine Bluestem Woodland’ is no longer the most prevalent vegetation type. Large areas of in the central and southeastern portion of the forest appear to have been converted to pasture and plantation, likely due to the low gradient associated with this community.
Some additional areas that were previously ‘Ozark-Ouachita Dry-Mesic Oak Forest’, ‘Ozark-Ouachita Shortleaf Pine-Oak Forest and Woodland’ and ‘Ozark-Ouachita Dry-Mesic Oak Forest’ have been converted to plantation.
The southwestern portion of the forest represents the most development, with the majority of the area now converted from ‘West Gulf Coastal Plain Pine-Hardwood Forest’ and ‘Gulf and Atlantic Coastal Plain Floodplain Systems’ to pasture and plantation.
The Ouachita National Forest remains heavily forested, as indicated by the Existing Vegetation Cover and Existing Vegetation Height.

title: Present: Current Ecosystem Conditions
text:
Existing Vegetation Cover
The Existing Vegetation Cover (EVC) map is a visual representation of EVC classifications across the subregion. The chart below the map provides a breakdown of each vegetation cover classification and their relative distribution across the forest.

title: Present: Current Ecosystem Conditions
text:
Existing Vegetation Height
The Existing Vegetation Height (EVH) map showcases EVH across the forest. The chart below the map provides the percentage of the landscape represented by each EVH height.
